articles.headline: As Smoke Clears in Beirut, Shock Turns to Anger
articles.snippet: As residents picked up the pieces, many saw the explosion as the culmination of years of mismanagement and neglect by Lebanon’s political leaders.
articles.abstract: As residents picked up the pieces, many saw the explosion as the culmination of years of mismanagement and neglect by Lebanon’s political leaders.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Since an orphaned shipment of highly explosive chemicals arrived at the port of Beirut in 2013, Lebanese officials treated it the way they have dealt with the country’s lack of electricity, poisonous tap water and overflowing garbage: by bickering and hoping the problem might solve itself.

articles.headline: Biden’s Milwaukee Trip Is Canceled, and So Is a Normal Presidential Campaign
articles.snippet: The Democrats bowed to the realities of the pandemic and canceled the major in-person speeches that were still planned for their convention this month.
articles.abstract: The Democrats bowed to the realities of the pandemic and canceled the major in-person speeches that were still planned for their convention this month.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Joseph R. Biden Jr. acknowledged on Wednesday that he would not appear in Milwaukee to accept the presidential nomination he has sought on and off since the 1980s, bowing to the realities of a pandemic that has altered every aspect of life in 2020, including the November contest.
articles.byline: By Reid J. Epstein and Katie Glueck

articles.headline: In Stimulus Talks, McConnell Is Outside the Room and in a Tight Spot
articles.snippet: With Republicans divided and President Trump undercutting negotiations on a pandemic relief package, the majority leader is in a difficult bind, partly of his own making.
articles.abstract: With Republicans divided and President Trump undercutting negotiations on a pandemic relief package, the majority leader is in a difficult bind, partly of his own making.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Mitch McConnell has put himself in one of the toughest spots of a political life that has seen plenty of them.

articles.headline: U.S. Examines Whether Saudi Nuclear Program Could Lead to Bomb Effort
articles.snippet: Intelligence agencies are scrutinizing whether the kingdom’s work with China to develop nuclear expertise is cover to process uranium and move toward development of a weapon.
articles.abstract: Intelligence agencies are scrutinizing whether the kingdom’s work with China to develop nuclear expertise is cover to process uranium and move toward development of a weapon.
articles.lead_paragraph: American intelligence agencies are scrutinizing efforts by Saudi Arabia to build up its ability to produce nuclear fuel that could put the kingdom on a path to developing nuclear weapons.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti, David E. Sanger and William J. Broad

articles.headline: A Family Cries ‘Justice for Hannah.’ Will Its Rural Town Listen?
articles.snippet: People in rural areas are killed in police shootings at about the same rate as in cities, but victims’ families and activists say they have struggled to get justice or even make themselves heard.
articles.abstract: People in rural areas are killed in police shootings at about the same rate as in cities, but victims’ families and activists say they have struggled to get justice or even make themselves heard.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEDALIA, Mo. — Seven weeks had passed, and still there were no answers. So once again, a small cluster of friends and family gathered in the leafy courthouse square and marched for Hannah Fizer, an unarmed woman shot and killed by a rural Missouri sheriff’s deputy during a traffic stop.

articles.headline: ‘It’s Time for a Change’: Workers Idled by the Virus Try New Careers
articles.snippet: Facing a loss of hours, unsecured wages and slow reopenings, some unemployed Britons are reconsidering their livelihoods.
articles.abstract: Facing a loss of hours, unsecured wages and slow reopenings, some unemployed Britons are reconsidering their livelihoods.
articles.lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, England — As a national lockdown was imposed in March, a food deliverer, Hanna Scaife, watched her weekly hours plummet from 30, to five, then to zero as restaurants across Teesside, in northeast England, shut their doors.

articles.headline: Witnessing Nuclear Carnage, Then Devoting Her Life to Peace
articles.snippet: Setsuko Thurlow, a survivor of the atomic bombing in Hiroshima 75 years ago, has used the power of her personal story to try to rid the world of nuclear weapons.
articles.abstract: Setsuko Thurlow, a survivor of the atomic bombing in Hiroshima 75 years ago, has used the power of her personal story to try to rid the world of nuclear weapons.
articles.lead_paragraph: On the morning of Aug. 6, 1945, Setsuko Thurlow, then just 13, reported for her first full day of duty in Japan’s increasingly desperate war effort. Together with 30 other girls, she had been recruited to assist with code breaking at a military office in Hiroshima.

articles.headline: The Unique U.S. Failure to Control the Virus
articles.snippet: Slowing the coronavirus has been especially difficult for the United States because of its tradition of prioritizing individualism and missteps by the Trump administration.
articles.abstract: Slowing the coronavirus has been especially difficult for the United States because of its tradition of prioritizing individualism and missteps by the Trump administration.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nearly every country has struggled to contain the coronavirus and made mistakes along the way.
articles.byline: By David Leonhardt and Lauren Leatherby

articles.headline: New York Attorney General Sues N.R.A. and Seeks Its Closure
articles.snippet: Letitia James seeks to dissolve the National Rifle Association, which was founded in New York, amid corruption allegations.
articles.abstract: Letitia James seeks to dissolve the National Rifle Association, which was founded in New York, amid corruption allegations.
articles.lead_paragraph: New York’s attorney general issued an existential challenge to the National Rifle Association on Thursday, arguing in a lawsuit that years of runaway corruption and misspending demanded the dissolution of the nation’s most powerful gun rights lobby.
